articles.headline: Lurid Lawsuit’s Quiet End Leaves Silicon Valley Start-Up Barely Dented
articles.snippet: For all the outcry over how women are treated in the tech industry, the resolution of a sexual harassment case against Upload, a virtual reality start-up, shows that little has changed.
articles.abstract: For all the outcry over how women are treated in the tech industry, the resolution of a sexual harassment case against Upload, a virtual reality start-up, shows that little has changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At Upload, the parties never seemed to stop.

articles.headline: Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge.
articles.snippet: Dogecoin was meant to poke fun at the hype around virtual currency. But now, its creator says, Dogecoin illustrates the risks.
articles.abstract: Dogecoin was meant to poke fun at the hype around virtual currency. But now, its creator says, Dogecoin illustrates the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jackson Palmer no longer thinks it’s funny to imitate Doge, the internet meme about a Shiba Inu dog whose awe-struck expressions and garbled syntax (e.g. “Wow. So pizza. Much delicious.”) made him a viral sensation several years ago.

articles.headline: With Chelsea Manning Invitation, Harvard Got a Discussion It Didn’t Want
articles.snippet: After the university’s Kennedy School gave Manning a visiting fellowship, backlash led to a reversal and criticism from across the political spectrum.
articles.abstract: After the university’s Kennedy School gave Manning a visiting fellowship, backlash led to a reversal and criticism from across the political spectrum.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — For Jim Pershing, who aspires to a career in international relations, studying at Harvard’s John F. Kennedy School of Government was a chance to immerse himself in a heady ecosystem where power players from the top echelons of the state, the nonprofit sector, the military and the media all converge.

articles.headline: Bump in U.S. Incomes Doesn’t Erase 50 Years of Pain
articles.snippet: Recent trends have produced positive statistics, but forces undermining the middle class may reach back farther than many economists have thought.
articles.abstract: Recent trends have produced positive statistics, but forces undermining the middle class may reach back farther than many economists have thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Incomes are up. Poverty is down. And job openings have hit a record high. But if the economy is so wonderful, why are so many Americans still feeling left behind?

articles.headline: Chips Off the Old Block: Computers Are Taking Design Cues From Human Brains
articles.snippet: New technologies are testing the limits of computer semiconductors. To deal with that, researchers have gone looking for ideas from nature.
articles.abstract: New technologies are testing the limits of computer semiconductors. To deal with that, researchers have gone looking for ideas from nature.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — We expect a lot from our computers these days. They should talk to us, recognize everything from faces to flowers, and maybe soon do the driving. All this artificial intelligence requires an enormous amount of computing power, stretching the limits of even the most modern machines.

articles.headline: U.S. Expands Kabul Security Zone, Digging In for Next Decade
articles.snippet: The remaking of the Afghan capital almost triples the footprint of a fortresslike Green Zone to take in nearly all ministries and Western compounds.
articles.abstract: The remaking of the Afghan capital almost triples the footprint of a fortresslike Green Zone to take in nearly all ministries and Western compounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Soon, American Embassy employees in Kabul will no longer need to take a Chinook helicopter ride to cross the street to a military base less than 100 yards outside the present Green Zone security district.

articles.headline: Cake Is His ‘Art.’ So Can He Deny One to a Gay Couple?
articles.snippet: A Colorado case that pits a gay couple against a baker who refused to serve them will mostly center on the protections of free speech.
articles.abstract: A Colorado case that pits a gay couple against a baker who refused to serve them will mostly center on the protections of free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKEWOOD, Colo. — Jack Phillips bakes beautiful cakes, and it is not a stretch to call him an artist. Five years ago, in a decision that has led to a Supreme Court showdown, he refused to use his skills to make a wedding cake to celebrate a same-sex marriage, saying it would violate his Christian faith and hijack his right to express himself.

articles.headline: Saved From Harvey’s Floodwaters, Twice. So How Did She End Up Dead?
articles.snippet: A Houston great-grandmother was put on a rescue boat. That much is known. But how she got off, was rescued a second time and then ended up in the morgue is one of Hurricane Harvey’s mysteries.
articles.abstract: A Houston great-grandmother was put on a rescue boat. That much is known. But how she got off, was rescued a second time and then ended up in the morgue is one of Hurricane Harvey’s mysteries.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It was a hard choice, but in the end it was no choice at all. A small rescue boat had come up the driveway, offering help. Carl Ellis was with his frail, 73-year-old mother, Wilma Jean. The boat had room for one.

articles.headline: The Big Question as the U.N. Gathers: What to Make of Trump?
articles.snippet: All eyes will be on the new American president at his first United Nations General Assembly as international leaders take his measure.
articles.abstract: All eyes will be on the new American president at his first United Nations General Assembly as international leaders take his measure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every year, the president heads to New York to welcome world leaders to the United Nations General Assembly. He gives a speech and meets with an endless string of foreign potentates to discuss a dizzying array of complicated, often intractable issues.

articles.headline: Rohingya Militants Vow to Fight Myanmar Despite Disastrous Cost
articles.snippet: Concern is rising that Rohingya Muslims — both militants and those displaced in recent attacks — will be exploited by international terrorist groups.
articles.abstract: Concern is rising that Rohingya Muslims — both militants and those displaced in recent attacks — will be exploited by international terrorist groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALUKHALI, Bangladesh — Nazir Hossain, the imam of a village in far western Myanmar, gathered the faithful around him after evening prayers last month. In a few hours, more than a dozen Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army fighters from his village would strike a nearby police post with an assortment of handmade weapons.

articles.headline: Who’d Create a P.R. Crisis on Purpose? Well, Only the Sweat Was Real
articles.snippet: The Times’s advertising reporter found out what it’s like to be a brand in the middle of a social-media-driven disaster.
articles.abstract: The Times’s advertising reporter found out what it’s like to be a brand in the middle of a social-media-driven disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just as I was stammering out some version of “no comment” to a reporter from BuzzFeed, my editor was about to field a call from The New York Post. Our company’s reputation was careening out of control, and we had no idea how to stop the damage — or slow the seemingly endless torrent of social media posts that were berating us for our ties to the world’s largest polluter.

articles.headline: The Rare, Potent Fuel Powering North Korea’s Weapons
articles.snippet: Despite a long record of intelligence warnings, there is no evidence that Washington has ever moved with urgency to cut off Pyongyang’s access to a rocket fuel.
articles.abstract: Despite a long record of intelligence warnings, there is no evidence that Washington has ever moved with urgency to cut off Pyongyang’s access to a rocket fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: When North Korea launched long-range missiles this summer, and again on Friday, demonstrating its ability to strike Guam and perhaps the United States mainland, it powered the weapons with a rare, potent rocket fuel that American intelligence agencies believe initially came from China and Russia.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Rolling Stone, Once a Counterculture Bible, Will Be Put Up for Sale
articles.snippet: After 50 years, the magazine founded and nurtured by Jann Wenner is bowing to the pressures of a troubled industry.
articles.abstract: After 50 years, the magazine founded and nurtured by Jann Wenner is bowing to the pressures of a troubled industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: From a loft in San Francisco in 1967, a 21-year-old named Jann S. Wenner started a magazine that would become the counterculture bible for baby boomers. Rolling Stone defined cool, cultivated literary icons and produced star-making covers that were such coveted real estate they inspired a song.

articles.headline: Trump Lawyers Clash Over How Much to Cooperate With Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: The debate, which led to an angry confrontation between two members of the legal team, could shape the course of the special counsel’s investigation.
articles.abstract: The debate, which led to an angry confrontation between two members of the legal team, could shape the course of the special counsel’s investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s legal team is wrestling with how much to cooperate with the special counsel looking into Russian election interference, an internal debate that led to an angry confrontation last week between two White House lawyers and that could shape the course of the investigation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Facebook Knows More About Russia’s Election Meddling. Shouldn’t We?
articles.snippet: The social media giant owes it to its users to let them know if they interacted with what amounts to a digital spy. And that’s just the start.
articles.abstract: The social media giant owes it to its users to let them know if they interacted with what amounts to a digital spy. And that’s just the start.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s what we know, so far, about Facebook’s recent disclosure that a shadowy Russian firm with ties to the Kremlin created thousands of ads on the social media platform that ran before, during and after the 2016 presidential election:

articles.headline: Facebook Faces a New World as Officials Rein In a Wild Web
articles.snippet: The web is not as open as it once was, with nation-states exerting their power over the internet. Facebook and other tech companies are dealing with the consequences.
articles.abstract: The web is not as open as it once was, with nation-states exerting their power over the internet. Facebook and other tech companies are dealing with the consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a muggy, late spring evening, Tuan Pham awoke to the police storming his house in Hanoi, Vietnam.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Mark Scott and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: A Down Payment With a Catch: You Must Be an Airbnb Host
articles.snippet: A start-up in Seattle will lend money to home buyers who promise to make a room available for rent continuously for up to three years.
articles.abstract: A start-up in Seattle will lend money to home buyers who promise to make a room available for rent continuously for up to three years.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If only we had the down payment” may be one of the most frequent complaints among aspiring home buyers in cities across the country.

articles.headline: Obamacare Repeal, Thought Dead in July, May Be Revived in Senate
articles.snippet: A long-shot effort by Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy to repeal the Affordable Care Act got new life on Monday, with a showdown vote possible soon.
articles.abstract: A long-shot effort by Senators Lindsey Graham and Bill Cassidy to repeal the Affordable Care Act got new life on Monday, with a showdown vote possible soon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act sprang back to life on Monday as Senate Republicans pushed for a showdown vote on new legislation that would do away with many of the health law’s requirements and bundle its funding into giant block grants to the states.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan
